docBody.head: Awareness of Birth Control Growing World-Wide, States Pioneer in Field, Margaret Sanger Slee

div.p: "It is everywhere evident that the awareness of the need of birth control in Asia is far ahead of the material to meet that need," commented Mrs. Margaret Sanger Slee, leader of the international birth control movement, on the overpopulation problem of Asia.

p.q: It was hard to imagine, sitting there with her in the quiet spaciousness of her Tucson home, that only a few weeks ago, she had been traveling extensively in the hot, overcrowded countries of Asia.

She left her home, 65 Sierra Vista Drive in October to attend the Third International Planned Parenthood Conference, held in late November in Bombay, India. En route there she visited Japan, Hong Kong, Singapore, and Ceylon.

During her 1--day visit in Japan, Mrs. Slee was the guest of the Mainichi Press. Her agenda was a busy one, including speeches and discussions every day. The places she spoke were nearly always crowded to the walls and it was not at all unusual for audiences numbering over a thousand to hear her speak.

div.p: As her ship docked at Yokohama, Mrs. Slee was impressed with the change in architecture. "A city which one had been oriental is now completely western," she remarked. "More people seemed to be in modern dress, also."

"The attitude of the Japanese people has changed," Mrs. Slee stated. "Formerly it was the desire for a number of children to guarantee the living of the old, and now it seems to be the desire for only two children in a family."

div.head: Ideal Number
div.p: At a meeting of midwives, nurses and welfare workers, questions were invited as to the ideal number and spacing of children. The majority said "Three, with three year spacing." Over half of the group had two children, some had three, and only four had as many as five children.

p.q: However over one million abortions (which are legal in Japan) are reported to have taken place in 1950 in that country.

div.p: "The government (of Japan) recently legalized birth control, the first in the world to take this step. Unfortunately an adequate education program has not been worked out, one which stresses the important fact that abortion is not contraception, that there are better and safer ways of spacing pregnancies and limiting families," Mrs. Slee stated in a recent article on Japan which appeared in the Dec. 13 issue of the "Nation".

"Nowhere in the world is there more need for planned parenthood than in Japan. The population, which was too great in 1922 for the land to support, was then 66 million. But now 85 million people are depending on the land for their welfare," she said.

"Japan is compact," Mrs. Slee remarked, "and the cruel ravages of war are not noticable. She still has her shrines and temples, her flower gardens, tea-houses and beautiful theaters. She is still a land of beauty, courtesy, color and charm."

div.head: Travels in Ceylon, Siam
div.p: Ceylon and Siam are anxious to organize a birth control movement there, but as yet have not been able to do so. While in Bankgok, Mrs. Slee talked with 50 young women doctors who were eager for the information. "Singapore and Hong Kong," she said "have clinics established under the British government."

p.q: While in India, Mrs. Slee had dinner with Nehru. He expressed to her that child welfare in India must be accomplished on a mass scale and that hunger is the first thing to be defeated.

Fourteen nations attended the conference held in Bombay where the international committee for planned parenthood organized into an international federation. Lady Rama Rau was elected director of the Orient by unanimous vote, and Mrs. Slee was named director of North America.
The organization has London as its headquarters and plans its next meeting for 1953 in Stockholm.

A gift of $2500 was sent by Tucson women to set up the first research clinic for Planned Parenthood in India. Actually this clinic, which has now been set up, is the first clinic for research purposes only, in all of Asia.

Dr. S. Radhakrishnan, vice-president of India, gave a speech at the conference which particularly impressed Mrs. Slee. One of the most important points of the speech was his courageous statement taking issue with Gandhi, who advocated abstinence, self-control and rhythm as the only means for limiting population; since anything else, Gandhi believed, was an interference with nature.

Dr. Radhakrishnan pointed out that self-control and abstinence is an interference with nature. Rhythm, too, he observed, is an interference with nature, and by the use of rhythm,once recognizes a justification in the marital relationship apart from parenthood, just as one would by the use of contraceptives.

A magazine reporting the progress of the planned parenthood movement is available to any interested person at no charge. Entitled "Population Bulletin," the magazine may be obtained by writing to 501 Madison avenue, New York city.
